span.h1: Updated: Here’s a rundown of OC school closures and grab-and-go meal schedules

img.alt: School staff handing sack lunch to person in car
img.p: Daniela Ballard, food service worker at Hidden Hills Elementary in Capistrano Unified, hands out free curbside school lunches. (Photo by Steven Georges/Cornerstone Communications)

section.p: To help prevent the spread of COVID-19, Orange County public schools have temporarily closed campuses to students. Here’s a look at the latest school closure timelines and grab-and-go meal schedules.
CAMPUSES CLOSED: Students will participate in distance learning for the remainder of the school year.
GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Open to all children 18 years and under. No paperwork or sign-ups necessary.
TIMES: 11 a.m. to noon

ul.li: Katella High School, 2200 E Wagner Ave, Anaheim
Anaheim High School, 811 W Lincoln Ave, Anaheim
Sycamore Junior High School, 1801 E Sycamore St, Anaheim
Loara High School, 1765 W Cerritos Ave, Anaheim
Brookhurst Junior High School, 601 N Brookhurst St, Anaheim
Western High School, 501 S. Western Ave, Anaheim
Kennedy High School, 8281 Walker Street, La Palma
Ponderosa Elementary School, 2135 South Mountain View Ave. Anaheim
Franklin Elementary School, 521 W. Water Street, Anaheim
Henry Elementary School, 1123 W. Romneya Drive Anaheim
Juarez Elementary School, 841 S. Sunkist St. Anaheim
Lincoln Elementary School, 1413 E Broadway, Anaheim
Revere Elementary School, 140 W. Guinida Lane, Anaheim
Stoddard Elementary School, 1841 S. Ninth St., Anaheim

section.p: CAMPUSES CLOSED: Students will participate in distance learning for the remainder of the school year.
GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Open to all children 18 years and under. No paperwork or sign-ups necessary.
TIMES: 11 a.m. to noon

ul.li: Katella High, 2200 E. Wagner Ave., Anaheim
Anaheim High, 811 W. Lincoln Ave., Anaheim
Sycamore Junior High, 1801 E Sycamore St., Anaheim
Loara High, 1765 West Cerritos, Anaheim
Brookhurst Junior High, 601 N. Brookhurst St., Anaheim
Western High, 501 S. Western Ave, Anaheim
Kennedy High, 8281 Walker Street, La Palma
Ponderosa Elementary, 2135 South Mountain View Ave. Anaheim

img.alt: School staff serving meals

section.p: CAMPUSES CLOSED: Students will participate in distance learning for the remainder of the school year.
GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Breakfast and lunch served to students 18 years and younger regardless of school. No paperwork required.
TIMES: 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.

ul.li: Arovista Elementary, 900 Eadington Drive, Brea
Country Hills Elementary,150 N Associated Rd, Brea
Laurel Elementary, 200 S Flower Ave, Brea (breakfast only from 8 to 9 a.m.)
Brea Junior High, 400 N Brea Blvd, Brea (breakfast only from 8 to 9 a.m.)
Brea Olinda High, 789 Wildcat Way, Brea (breakfast only from 8 to 9 a.m.)

section.p: CAMPUSES CLOSED: Students will participate in distance learning for the remainder of the school year.
GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: All students ages 18 and under are eligible for meals even if they do not attend a BPSD school.
TIMES: 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 11:30 am. to 12:30 p.m.

ul.li: Gordon H. Beatty, 8201 Country Club Drive, Buena Park
Buena Park Junior High, 6931 Orangethorpe Ave., Buena Park

img.alt: School staff handing sack lunch to person in car
img.p: CUSD Food Service Worker Jenny Willett hands out free curbside school lunches as cars line up at Hidden Hills Elementary. (Photo by Steven Georges/Cornerstone Communications

section.p: CAMPUSES CLOSED: School campuses will be closed to students through June 4.

GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Open to any child 18 years and under regardless of what school they attend. CUSD will additionally provide a sack breakfast for the following morning, containing a bar or cereal cup with fruit and milk.
TIMES: 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m.

ul.li: Monday: Two breakfast and two lunch meals will be served.
Wednesday: Three breakfast and three lunch meals will be served.
San Juan Elementary, 31642 El Camino Real, San Juan Capistrano
Las Palmas Elementary, 1101 Calle Puenta, San Clemente
Hidden Hills Elementary, 25142 Hidden Hills Road, Laguna Nigel
Marco Forester Middle, 25601 Camino Del Avion, San Juan Capistrano
RH Dana Elementary, 24242 La Cresta Dr., Dana Point
Wood Canyon Elementary School, 23431 Knollwood, Aliso Viejo
Las Flores Elementary, 25862 Antonio Parkway, Rancho Santa Margarita
Carl Hankey K8 School, 27252 Nubles, Mission Viejo

section.p: CAMPUSES CLOSED: School campuses will be closed to students through May 8.
GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Breakfast and lunch offered three days a week to all children 18 or under, March 30 through May 8.​
TIMES: 10 a.m. to 12:00 p.m.

ul.li: Monday: Meals will be provided for Monday and Tuesday.
Wednesday: Meals will be provided for Wednesday and Thursday.
Friday: Meals will be provided.
Walter Knott Education Center, 7300 La Palma Avenue, Buena Park
Danbrook Elementary, 320 Danbrook St., Anaheim
San Marino Elementary, 6215 San Rolando Way, Buena Park

section.p: CAMPUSES CLOSED: Students will participate in distance learning for the remainder of the school year.
GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Breakfast and lunch offered to all children 18 years and under. No sign-up required. May pick-up from any school.
TIMES: 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.
Weekly schedule:

ul.li: Monday: Two breakfast and two lunch meals will be served.
Wednesday: Two breakfast and two lunch meals will be served.
Friday: One breakfast and one lunch meal will be served.

section.p: Special Memorial Day holiday schedule:

ul.li: Friday, May 22: Two breakfast and two lunch meals will be served.
Monday, May 25: No meal distribution
Tuesday, May 26: One breakfast and one lunch meal will be served.
Wednesday, May 27: Regular weekly schedule resumes.

TIMES: 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m.

GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Breakfast and lunch offered to all children under the age of 18.
TIMES: 11 a.m. to 1 p.m.

ul.li: March 23 – 27: Monday through Thursday
Starting March 30: Monday through Friday

section.p: LOCATIONS: All school sites except Parks Jr. High, Ladera Vista Jr. High and Nicolas Jr. High

GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Breakfast and lunch are open to those who participate in the free and reduced lunch program.
TIMES: 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.
DISTRIBUTION DAYS: Monday through Friday
LOCATIONS: Available for pick-up in school cafeterias
CAMPUSES CLOSED: Students will participate in distance learning for the remainder of the school year.

GRAB-AND-GO SERVICE: Breakfast and lunch are offered two days a week to all children age 18 and under, as well as individuals with developmental disabilities who are age 21 and younger and enrolled in an institution or regional center program. Families will receive meals for Monday and Tuesday every Monday and meals for Wednesday through Friday every Wednesday.
TIMES: 11 a.m. to 1 p.m.
DISTRIBUTION DAYS: Monday and Wednesday

a.span: Happy Earth Day! Remember, we only have one. #eart

a.span: Every year around this time, OCDE and VSA Orange C

img.alt: Every year around this time, OCDE and VSA Orange County team up to spotlight the artistic achievements of individuals with disabilities.⁣ ⁣ The VSA Festival is a free, daylong event that’s typically held at MainPlace Mall in Santa Ana on a Saturday in April. But California’s stay-at-home directive and national social distancing measures mean the 44th annual celebration will look a bit different.⁣ ⁣ Instead of an in-person experience, organizers have created a virtual festival, featuring links to a 200-piece art gallery, 15 performance videos, video messages from special guests and educational activities to help students learn more about individuals with disabilities.⁣ ⁣ The virtual celebration launches today, April 18, and can be found here:⁣ ⁣ https://sites.google.com/prod/ocde.us/vsaocfestival⁣ ⁣ Visit the OCDE Newsroom for more information. #oc #OCArtsforALL #specialeducation #idea #imaginationcelebration

a.span: OCDE is currently looking to hire a Senior Payroll

img.alt: OCDE is currently looking to hire a Senior Payroll Technician to help the agency support the programs and services it offers. To apply and to see other positions, visit: https://www.edjoin.org/ocde #WorkatOCDE #OCSchoolCareers #jobopenings #jobs

a.span: Kyo Pineda, Title I program supervisor in OCDE’s

img.alt:
Kyo Pineda, Title I program supervisor in OCDE’s ACCESS program, is doing her part to help COVID-19 first responders. Pineda has been spending much of her free time over the last couple of weeks building protective face shields using her Cricut cutting machine, a device designed to cut hundreds of materials including paper, fabric, leather and balsa wood for DIY projects. Read more at Newsroom.ocde.us.
#COVID19 #PPE #volunteers @ppeposse

a.span: The 2020 U.S. Census is here. This is one of the f

img.alt: The 2020 U.S. Census is here. This is one of the few national activities the American public does together. It’s also easy, confidential and critically important to our students and their communities. Learn more at https://newsroom.ocde.us/2020-census-step-up-and-be-counted-or-help-others-do-so/ #census2020 #census #OCcensus2020

a.span: Teachers, do you need some technical tips for your

img.alt: Teachers, do you need some technical tips for your video lessons? Our OCDE Media Services team has put together some information to help incorporate video into daily teaching like Zoom classrooms, or pre-recorded lessons for platforms like Canvas. This first tip is on lighting.

a.span: On Friday, March 13, school districts across Orang

img.alt: On Friday, March 13, school districts across Orange County made the difficult decision to temporarily dismiss students in response to COVID-19 fears and calls for social distancing. At the time we found it necessary to hit the pause button so we could better understand the novel coronavirus and its transmission. Many of our districts announced campus closures of two to three weeks and later extended those timelines based on guidance from state and local health officials.⁣ ⁣ This has placed our schools in a holding pattern, and it has been difficult for families to make long-term plans. Now, as we enter a new phase in our understanding of the threat, it is time to address the reality that our efforts to flatten the curve and keep students safe cannot be accomplished in the span of a few weeks or even a month. Even President Trump has called for social distancing measures to continue through April, which for many of our districts would leave only a few weeks to wrap up the school year. Therefore, in alignment with today’s statements from Governor Gavin Newsom and State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond, I am recommending that school districts in Orange County cancel student attendance on campuses through the end of this academic year and channel their efforts toward adopting robust and effective distance learning models.⁣ ⁣ Read the full statement at newsroom.ocde.us

a.span: Hundreds of school staff and community members fro

img.alt: Hundreds of school staff and community members from across OC have worked tirelessly since campuses closed to ensure all children have access to a nutritious breakfast and lunch. Our Media Services team chronicled some of their hard work in this video #grabandgo #schoollunches

a.span: OCDE’s Deaf and Hard of Hearing team has a messa

img.alt:
OCDE’s Deaf and Hard of Hearing team has a message for students who can’t be at school and are probably missing other aspects of life in Orange County — like trips to Disneyland⁣ ⁣ You can watch the full video at: https://newsroom.ocde.us/
Inspired by social media, counselor Kim Coronado came up with the idea and enlisted the DHH staff, including the principal, teachers, paraeducators, interpreters, the school psychologist, an audiologist, the school nurse, an administrative assistant, and a speech and language pathologist. Teacher Chris Gonzales edited the clips together.⁣ ⁣ “All I know is, after the hardest week I’ve ever endured as not only an educator but a human, I woke up more invigorated than I have all week,” Principal David Longo told his team. “We will get through this, and I feel that more than I ever have.”⁣ ⁣ Based at Venado Middle School and University High School in Irvine Unified, the Orange County Department of Education’s DHH program serves more than 135 students from districts throughout Orange County.⁣ ⁣ #OC #publichealth #ocde #publicschool #covid_19 #disney #itsasmallworld #disneyland #socialdistancing

a.span: As we navigate through this difficult time, it can

img.alt: As we navigate through this difficult time, it can be especially tough on our children. Here's a short video created by OCDE's Media Services team with some tips for families to better support kids now spending nearly all their time at home. #health #mentalhealth #staysafe

a.span: We’ve heard a lot about social distancing lately

img.alt:
We’ve heard a lot about social distancing lately, and you might have also heard the term “flattening the curve.” The two concepts are connected.
The idea is that minimizing social contact can effectively slow the spread of a virus so you don’t get a huge wave of illnesses all at once. If that were too happen, a community might not have enough hospital beds or staff to manage patient care.
As explained in this brief video produced by OCDE’s Media Services, infectious disease experts say it helps to spread cases out over weeks or months so that health care systems can keep pace. #flattenthecurve #COVID19 #staysafe

a.span: To help curb the spread of #COVID-19, Orange Count

img.alt:
To help curb the spread of #COVID-19, Orange County public schools are on an extended hiatus for at least the next two weeks. But that doesn’t mean students won’t have access to healthy meals.
In fact, most local districts are offering nutritious grab-and-go meals to any student 18 years and younger, regardless of where they go to school. Take a look at the school districts offering meals in your area by visiting Newsroom.OCDE.us.
#grab-and-go #schoollunches #staysafe

a.span: Schools districts across Orange County are working

img.alt:
Schools districts across Orange County are working to offer distance learning programs for students while schools remained closed because of the #COVID-19 threat. Many teachers will be communicating with families to determine the best ways to engage with students to limit educational disruption during these challenging times.
Meanwhile, go to Newsroom.OCDE.us for some free online resources for students to help supplement other materials that are being provided.

a.span: UPDATE: Nearly all Orange County public schools wi

img.alt: UPDATE: Nearly all Orange County public schools will be closed to students through at least March 27 as a precaution during the ongoing #COVIDー19 threat. Some districts will be closed longer with spring breaks rolled into the closures. (Note: Tustin Unified has spring break through March 23. District officials are assessing whether to extend the break beyond that date. But no determination has yet been made.) Check with your individual districts for more details. Visit Newsroom.OCDE.us for the latest information. #coronavirus #staysafe

a.span: Important message from OC Supt. of Schools regardi

img.alt:
Important message from OC Supt. of Schools regarding #COVID-19
As a precautionary step to slow and prevent the spread of COVID-19, and after careful deliberations with local school district leaders and in consultation with the OC Health Care Agency, I hereby support the decision of schools and districts in our county to suspend all activity for a minimum of 14 days.
This is not a decision we take lightly. We know that temporarily closing a school has a tremendous impact on our families, and steps will need to be implemented to support the continuity of learning and to ensure students have access to healthy meals. But the safety of our students and staff remains our top priority, and we have confidence that this is the proper precautionary course for Orange County.
At this time, county health officials believe the risk of transmission is low, and there has been no evidence of a case affecting a student or staff member at an Orange County school. The Orange County Health Care Agency continues to work with federal, state, and local partners including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) and health care providers on preparedness efforts and to guide appropriate care for those who may be at risk for illness associated with the virus.
The Orange County Department of Education has been stepping up its efforts to produce content and materials to help support learning at home. While it is not possible to replace an instructional day or provide comprehensive course content with online resources or take-home packets, we can develop resources and strategies to provide a continuity of learning.
Districts that dismiss students due to pandemics will be eligible to seek funding emergency relief through the California Department of Education’s J-13A waiver process. In addition, we are asking California leaders to provide credit for lost instructional time.
OCDE will continue to work diligently with local districts to make sure our schools and students are supported during and after this hiatus. Thank you for your efforts to keep our children and our communities safe. Read more at newsroom.ocde.us

a.span: Introducing Theresa Pham. ⁣ ⁣ Theresa is an Ap

img.alt: Introducing Theresa Pham. ⁣ ⁣ Theresa is an Applications Support Analyst in the Information Technology Division with OCDE.⁣ ⁣ She provides support to the Business applications such as Payroll, HR, and Time and Attendance. Although her technical skills are not a part of direct student learning, they do impact the teachers and administrators who serve OC students in the classroom by making sure their time and attendance is tracked correctly and they get paid on time and continue to work each day. “Another day at work for them is another opportunity to make a difference in the lives of our students.”⁣ ⁣ Theresa’s decision to work at the Orange County Department of Education was driven in part by the spirit of collaboration and teamwork that the organization promotes. “Being able to work with teams from other departments has allowed me to learn so much more about the great difference that OCDE makes in the community.”⁣ ⁣ #OCDEmakingaDifference⁣

a.span: #Coronavirus update: state health officials recomm

img.alt:
#Coronavirus update: state health officials recommend mass gatherings should be suspended through March.
The guidance does NOT apply to activities such as attendance at regular school, work, or essential services. It defines a gathering as any event that brings together people in single space at the same time, such as an auditorium, stadium, arena, large conferences.
Follow the latest updates at newsroom.ocde.us
